Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, as Mr. Goldstein’s voice crackled through the line. He was furious, convinced our latest offer was a scam, and demanded I explain every detail. My manager’s eyes flicked over, expecting me to keep him calm and close the sale. I tried to steady my voice, answering each objection, but my mind kept drifting to the lunch break ahead. Today was the company’s big communal meal, and I’d already seen the trays—none of the food was kosher, and there was no way to bring in my own. My coworkers expected me to join in, to be part of the team, but I couldn’t ignore my dietary laws. The pressure built as I juggled Mr. Goldstein’s questions and the knowledge that soon I’d have to choose between fitting in at work and staying true to my faith. My stomach twisted, not just from hunger, but from the weight of these clashing demands.
